clusters.title: Venezuela condemns Trump's threat to close country's airspace
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Says Venezuelan Airspace Should Be Considered Closed

items.title: Venezuela condemns Trump's threat to close country's airspace
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump says airspace over Venezuela should be considered closed "in its entirety" as tensions mount between the two countries.
items.content: US President Donald Trump says airspace over Venezuela should be considered closed "in its entirety" as tensions mount between the two countries.

items.title: Venezuela Condemns Trump Airspace Closure As 'Colonialist Threat,' Senate Democrats Raise War Powers Concerns
items.standfirst: Venezuela denounced President Donald Trump‘s airspace closure declaration, calling it a “colonialist threat” that undermines the nation’s sovereignty. The official statement issued described the action as “extravagant, illegal, and unjustified aggression against the people of…

items.title: Trump declares Venezuela's airspace closed
items.standfirst: President Trump intensified his pressure campaign on Venezuela on Saturday. He posted that the airspace around the country is "closed in its entirety." Weijia Jiang has more details.
items.content: President Trump intensified his pressure campaign on Venezuela on Saturday. He posted that the airspace around the country is "closed in its entirety." Weijia Jiang has more details.

items.title: Maduro’s government rejects Trump’s claim of closing Venezuelan airspace
items.standfirst: Venezuela’s government said it “forcefully rejects” Trump’s claim about closing the airspace and that it was a “colonial threat” intended to undermine the country's "territorial integrity, aeronautical security and full sovereignty.”
items.content: Venezuela’s government said it “forcefully rejects” Trump’s claim about closing the airspace and that it was a “colonial threat” intended to undermine the country's "territorial integrity, aeronautical security and full sovereignty.”

items.standfirst: Venezuela's Foreign Ministry rejected United States President Donald declaration on its skies. The ministry said the measure represented an attempt to interfere with national sovereignty and desc...
items.content: Venezuela's Foreign Ministry rejected United States President Donald declaration on its skies. The ministry said the measure represented an attempt to interfere with national sovereignty and desc...

items.title: Venezuela denounces ‘colonialist threat’ as Trump orders airspace closed
items.standfirst: President made declaration in a social media post, after FAA last week warned airlines of ‘worsening security situation’The Venezuelan government has responded defiantly to the heightened pressure by the US government, including Donald Trump’s recent statements on Saturday that the airspace above and surrounding Venezuela is to be closed in its entirety.In a statement, the Venezuelan government said Trump’s comments are a “colonialist threat” against their sovereignty and violate international law. The government also said it demanded respect for its airspace and would not accept foreign orders or threats. Continue reading...
items.content: President made declaration in a social media post, after FAA last week warned airlines of ‘worsening security situation’The Venezuelan government has responded defiantly to the heightened pressure by the US government, including Donald Trump’s recent statements on Saturday that the airspace above and surrounding Venezuela is to be closed in its entirety.In a statement, the Venezuelan government said Trump’s comments are a “colonialist threat” against their sovereignty and violate international law. The government also said it demanded respect for its airspace and would not accept foreign orders or threats. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says Venezuela airspace should be considered closed, Caracas slams 'colonialist threat'
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Saturday warned that the airspace above and around Venezuela should be considered closed, escalating tensions with Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro as Washington steps up a major military deployment in the Caribbean and strikes on alleged drug-smuggling vessels. Caracas slammed the warning as a "colonialist threat".
items.content: President Donald Trump on Saturday warned that the airspace above and around Venezuela should be considered closed, escalating tensions with Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro as Washington steps up a major military deployment in the Caribbean and strikes on alleged drug-smuggling vessels. Caracas slammed the warning as a "colonialist threat".

items.title: Venezuela hits out at 'colonial threat' after Trump 'closes' its airspace
items.standfirst: Venezuela has accused Donald Trump of making a "colonial threat," after the US president said the airspace "above and surrounding" the country should be considered closed "in its entirety".
items.content: Venezuela has accused Donald Trump of making a "colonial threat," after the US president said the airspace "above and surrounding" the country should be considered closed "in its entirety".

items.title: Trump tells airlines Venezuela's airspace is 'closed in its entirety' in latest escalation

items.content: President Donald Trump said Saturday morning that Venezuela’s airspace should be considered “closed” as he weighs military action against the South American nation.

items.title: At least four dead and 10 wounded in California shooting
items.standfirst: At least four people were killed and 10 others wounded when gunfire erupted during a family gathering at a Stockton banquet hall Saturday evening, in what local authorities say may have been a "targeted attack".
items.content: At least four people were killed and 10 others wounded when gunfire erupted during a family gathering at a Stockton banquet hall Saturday evening, in what local authorities say may have been a "targeted attack".

items.content: The suspect in the shooting remains at large, authorities said.

items.content: Four people were killed and 10 wounded in a shooting during a family gathering at a banquet hall in Stockton, sheriff's officials said Saturday.(Image credit: Ethan Swope)

clusters.title: Airlines in India Complete A320 Software Upgrades: Regulator

items.title: Airlines in India Complete A320 Software Upgrades: Regulator
items.standfirst: The Directorate General of Civil Aviation, India’s safety regulator, Sunday said airlines in the country have completed urgent software upgrades of the Airbus 320 family of aircraft.
items.content: The Directorate General of Civil Aviation, India’s safety regulator, Sunday said airlines in the country have completed urgent software upgrades of the Airbus 320 family of aircraft.

items.title: Airlines worldwide work to fix software glitch on A320 aircraft
items.standfirst: Airlines around the world reported short-term disruptions heading into the weekend as they fixed software on the widely used A320 family of aircraft. FRANCE 24 speaks to Anita Mendiratta, strategic advisor, author and diplomat specialising in tourism and aviation to better understand the situation.

FRANCE 24 speaks to Anita Mendiratta, strategic advisor, author and diplomat specialising in tourism and aviation to better understand the situation.

items.title: Airlines rush to fix Airbus A320 software glitch, disruptions reported
items.standfirst: Airlines worldwide on Saturday rushed to fix software on hundreds of Airbus A320s after a JetBlue jet’s sudden altitude drop exposed a solar radiation-linked glitch. There were short-term disruptions at several airports as US passengers prepared to return home after the Thanksgiving holiday, one of the busiest travel times in the country.
items.content: Airlines worldwide on Saturday rushed to fix software on hundreds of Airbus A320s after a JetBlue jet’s sudden altitude drop exposed a solar radiation-linked glitch. There were short-term disruptions at several airports as US passengers prepared to return home after the Thanksgiving holiday, one of the busiest travel times in the country.

items.title: Airbus issues major A320 recall after mid-air incident grounds planes, disrupting global travel
items.standfirst: Immediate software change on ‘significant number’ of jets to result in disruption to half the worldwide fleetAirlines around the world cancelled and delayed flights heading into the weekend after Airbus announced on Friday that it had ordered immediate repairs to 6,000 of its A320 family of jets in a recall affecting more than half of the global fleet.The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), which is the main certifying authority for A320 aircraft, issued the instruction on Friday night as a precautionary action, saying that “safety is paramount”. Continue reading...
items.content: Immediate software change on ‘significant number’ of jets to result in disruption to half the worldwide fleetAirlines around the world cancelled and delayed flights heading into the weekend after Airbus announced on Friday that it had ordered immediate repairs to 6,000 of its A320 family of jets in a recall affecting more than half of the global fleet.The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), which is the main certifying authority for A320 aircraft, issued the instruction on Friday night as a precautionary action, saying that “safety is paramount”. Continue reading...

items.title: Airbus rush to update A320 software after plane's sudden altitude drop
items.standfirst: Airlines around the world canceled and delayed flights heading into the weekend to fix software on a widely used commercial aircraft after an analysis found the computer code may have contributed to a sudden drop in the altitude of a JetBlue plane last month. Airbus said Friday that an examination of the JetBlue incident revealed that intense solar radiation may corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls on the A320 family of aircraft.
items.content: Airlines around the world canceled and delayed flights heading into the weekend to fix software on a widely used commercial aircraft after an analysis found the computer code may have contributed to a sudden drop in the altitude of a JetBlue plane last month. Airbus said Friday that an examination of the JetBlue incident revealed that intense solar radiation may corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls on the A320 family of aircraft.

items.title: Airbus Warns A320 Fleet Needs Software Fix After Incident
items.standfirst: Airbus SE cautioned that more than half of its active A320 jetliner family fleet will need a software fix after a recent incident involving a JetBlue Airways Corp. airliner revealed that “intense solar radiation” could corrupt data that helps maintain functioning flight controls.
items.content: Airbus SE cautioned that more than half of its active A320 jetliner family fleet will need a software fix after a recent incident involving a JetBlue Airways Corp. airliner revealed that “intense solar radiation” could corrupt data that helps maintain functioning flight controls.

ai_summary: Airbus ordered software upgrades for A320 family aircraft.
The software fix was due to solar radiation risk.
Global airlines worked to fix the software glitch.
U.S. airlines reported short-term disruptions.
Repairs were less burdensome than expected.

clusters.title: Live: Russian drone strike kills at least one, wounds 11 near Kyiv
clusters.neutral_headline: Russian Strikes Kill Three in Kyiv, Ukraine

items.title: Live: Russian drone strike kills at least one, wounds 11 near Kyiv
items.standfirst: A Russian drone attack killed at least one person and wounded 11 in Vyshgorod, outside of Kyiv, the regional governor said Sunday. The attack came ahead of a meeting between top Trump administration officials and Ukrainian negotiators in Florida which aims to broker an end to Russia's war in Ukraine and set the stage for key talks planned this week in Moscow with Russian leader Vladimir Putin. Follow the latest updates on FRANCE 24's liveblog.
items.content: A Russian drone attack killed at least one person and wounded 11 in Vyshgorod, outside of Kyiv, the regional governor said Sunday. The attack came ahead of a meeting between top Trump administration officials and Ukrainian negotiators in Florida which aims to broker an end to Russia's war in Ukraine and set the stage for key talks planned this week in Moscow with Russian leader Vladimir Putin. Follow the latest updates on FRANCE 24's liveblog.

items.title: Russian attacks kill 3 in Kyiv as Ukrainian delegation travels to U.S.
items.standfirst: Russian drone and missile attacks in and around the Ukrainian capital killed at least three people early Saturday, officials said.
items.content: Russian drone and missile attacks in and around the Ukrainian capital killed at least three people early Saturday, officials said.

items.title: Ukrainian sea drones target Russian oil tankers
items.standfirst: As Ukrainian officials prepare to resume talks toward a possible peace deal, Ukrainian sea drone attacks on Russian oil tankers is raising concerns that the continued fighting could prevent a deal from being reached. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez reports.
items.content: As Ukrainian officials prepare to resume talks toward a possible peace deal, Ukrainian sea drone attacks on Russian oil tankers is raising concerns that the continued fighting could prevent a deal from being reached. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez reports.

items.title: Russian strikes on Kyiv kill 3 as Ukrainian delegation heads to U.S. for talks to end war
items.standfirst: Russian drone and missile attacks in and around the Ukraine's capital killed at least three people early Saturday, officials said, as the country's representatives traveled to the U.S. to work on a renewed push to end the war.
items.content: Russian drone and missile attacks in and around the Ukraine's capital killed at least three people early Saturday, officials said, as the country's representatives traveled to the U.S. to work on a renewed push to end the war.

items.title: Ukrainian officials head to US for talks - as Russian tankers hit by 'Sea Baby' drones
items.standfirst: Ukraine's representatives are preparing for renewed peace talks in the US, while dramatic footage has shown Russian tankers being hit by naval drones.
items.content: Ukraine's representatives are preparing for renewed peace talks in the US, while dramatic footage has shown Russian tankers being hit by naval drones.

items.title: At least three killed in Russian drone and missile strikes on Ukraine
items.standfirst: Russian drone and missile attacks in and around the Ukraine's capital killed at least three people early Saturday, officials said. The Kyiv City Military Administration said two people were killed in the strikes on the capital, and a woman died, and eight were wounded in a combined missile and drone attack on the broader Kyiv region, according to the regional police.
items.content: Russian drone and missile attacks in and around the Ukraine's capital killed at least three people early Saturday, officials said. The Kyiv City Military Administration said two people were killed in the strikes on the capital, and a woman died, and eight were wounded in a combined missile and drone attack on the broader Kyiv region, according to the regional police.

ai_summary: Russian drone and missile attacks hit Kyiv and surrounding areas.
At least three people were killed in the attacks.
A Ukrainian delegation traveled to the U.S. for talks.
Ukrainian sea drones targeted Russian oil tankers.
The attacks occurred ahead of peace talks.

clusters.title: Pope visits Turkey's Blue Mosque for meeting with religious leaders
clusters.neutral_headline: Pope Visits Istanbul's Blue Mosque

items.title: Pope visits Turkey's Blue Mosque for meeting with religious leaders
items.standfirst: Pope Leo toured the 17th-century mosque, but did not pray there.
items.content: Pope Leo toured the 17th-century mosque, but did not pray there.

items.title: Pope Leo pushes for peace and unity at Blue Mosque in Turkey
items.standfirst: Pope Leo celebrated mass in Istanbul with Turkey's Catholic community on Saturday. He also visited the famous Blue Mosque to address peace and unity across faiths. Chris Livesay has more.
items.content: Pope Leo celebrated mass in Istanbul with Turkey's Catholic community on Saturday. He also visited the famous Blue Mosque to address peace and unity across faiths. Chris Livesay has more.

items.title: Pope visits Istanbul’s Blue Mosque without praying as he focuses on Christian unity
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV visited Istanbul’s iconic Blue Mosque on Saturday but didn't stop to pray, as he focused more on bolstering ties with Orthodox patriarchs and promoting courageous steps for Eastern and Western churches to be united.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV visited Istanbul’s iconic Blue Mosque on Saturday but didn't stop to pray, as he focused more on bolstering ties with Orthodox patriarchs and promoting courageous steps for Eastern and Western churches to be united.

items.title: Pope Leo visits Blue Mosque in Turkiye’s Istanbul
items.standfirst: The pope is visiting Turkiye until Sunday on his first overseas trip as pontiff, which also includes a visit to Lebanon.
items.content: The pope is visiting Turkiye until Sunday on his first overseas trip as pontiff, which also includes a visit to Lebanon.

items.title: Pope Leo visits Istanbul's Blue Mosque
items.standfirst: It is the first time Leo has attended a Muslim place of worship since he took up the papacy in May.
items.content: It is the first time Leo has attended a Muslim place of worship since he took up the papacy in May.

items.title: Pope Leo tours Istanbul’s Blue Mosque during Turkiye trip
items.standfirst: The Head of the Catholic Church, Pope Leo, visited Istanbul's Blue Mosque as part of his four-day trip to Turkiye.
items.content: The Head of the Catholic Church, Pope Leo, visited Istanbul's Blue Mosque as part of his four-day trip to Turkiye.

items.title: Pope Leo visits Istanbul's Blue Mosque during first overseas visit
items.standfirst: The Pope has visited Istanbul's Blue Mosque during a day spent meeting both Muslim and Christian leaders.
items.content: The Pope has visited Istanbul's Blue Mosque during a day spent meeting both Muslim and Christian leaders.

ai_summary: Pope Leo visited Istanbul's Blue Mosque.
The Pope did not pray during his visit.
He focused on Christian unity.
The visit was part of his first overseas trip.
The Pope met with Muslim and Christian leaders.

clusters.title: More than 70,000 killed in Gaza since Israel offensive began, Hamas-run health ministry says
clusters.neutral_headline: Gaza Death Toll Surpasses 70,000

items.title: More than 70,000 killed in Gaza since Israel offensive began, Hamas-run health ministry says
items.standfirst: Two young brothers were among the latest killed - reportedly in an Israeli air strike as the Gaza ceasefire remains fragile.
items.content: Two young brothers were among the latest killed - reportedly in an Israeli air strike as the Gaza ceasefire remains fragile.

items.title: Tens of thousands march across Europe in show of support for Palestinians
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands rallied in Paris on Saturday to show support for Palestinians in Gaza, as protesters accused Israel of violating a fragile US-brokered ceasefire and demanded tougher international action amid soaring death tolls and ongoing restrictions on aid. Gaza’s health ministry, run by Hamas, said Saturday that more than 70,000 people have been killed since the war began.
items.content: Tens of thousands rallied in Paris on Saturday to show support for Palestinians in Gaza, as protesters accused Israel of violating a fragile US-brokered ceasefire and demanded tougher international action amid soaring death tolls and ongoing restrictions on aid. Gaza’s health ministry, run by Hamas, said Saturday that more than 70,000 people have been killed since the war began.

items.title: Gaza death toll surpasses 70,000, says health ministry
items.standfirst: Two Palestinian children reportedly killed on Saturday as Israel continues its strikes after latest ceasefireThe Palestinian death toll has surpassed 70,000 since the Israel-Gaza war began, Gaza’s health ministry said on Saturday, while a hospital reported Israeli fire killed two Palestinian children in the territory’s south.The toll has continued to rise after the latest ceasefire took effect on 10 October. Israel still carries out strikes in response to what it has called violations of the truce, and bodies from earlier in the war are being recovered from the rubble. Continue reading...
items.content: Two Palestinian children reportedly killed on Saturday as Israel continues its strikes after latest ceasefireThe Palestinian death toll has surpassed 70,000 since the Israel-Gaza war began, Gaza’s health ministry said on Saturday, while a hospital reported Israeli fire killed two Palestinian children in the territory’s south.The toll has continued to rise after the latest ceasefire took effect on 10 October. Israel still carries out strikes in response to what it has called violations of the truce, and bodies from earlier in the war are being recovered from the rubble. Continue reading...

items.title: Palestinian death toll surpasses 70,000 since start of Israel-Hamas war, Gaza ministry says
items.standfirst: The Palestinian death toll has surpassed 70,000 since the Israel-Hamas war began, Gaza’s Health Ministry said Saturday, while a hospital said that Israeli fire killed two Palestinian children in the territory's south.
items.content: The Palestinian death toll has surpassed 70,000 since the Israel-Hamas war began, Gaza’s Health Ministry said Saturday, while a hospital said that Israeli fire killed two Palestinian children in the territory's south.

items.title: Two brothers killed in Israeli drone strike on Gaza
items.standfirst: An Israeli drone strike has killed two Palestinian children in southern Gaza, a hospital reported.
items.content: An Israeli drone strike has killed two Palestinian children in southern Gaza, a hospital reported.

ai_summary: The Gaza health ministry reported over 70,000 deaths.
Two children were reportedly killed in an Israeli strike.
Tens of thousands marched in Europe to support Palestinians.
The death toll has risen since the war began.
Israel continues strikes after the latest ceasefire.

clusters.title: What next for Ukraine after President Zelenskyy’s top aide quits?
clusters.neutral_headline: Zelenskyy's Top Aide Resigns Amid Corruption Probe

items.title: What next for Ukraine after President Zelenskyy’s top aide quits?
items.standfirst: Chief-of-Staff Andriy Yermak resigns after anticorruption raid.
items.content: Chief-of-Staff Andriy Yermak resigns after anticorruption raid.

items.title: Zelenskyy faces ‘mini-revolution’ as Yermak’s fall reshapes Ukraine’s wartime power system
items.standfirst: Exit of Zelenskyy’s most powerful aide could also have impact on Kyiv’s negotiating position in talks over ending warUkraine’s political system is bracing for a “mini-revolution” as the county’s president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, is forced to adapt to life without his closest adviser, chief enforcer and most loyal associate, Andriy Yermak, who resigned on Friday after his apartment was searched as part of a widening anti-corruption probe.Yermak’s resignation could have tremendous consequences for domestic governance, as well as for Ukraine’s negotiating position in talks over ending the war with Russia, where he had served as the head of Ukraine’s delegation to peace talks with the White House. Continue reading...
items.content: Exit of Zelenskyy’s most powerful aide could also have impact on Kyiv’s negotiating position in talks over ending warUkraine’s political system is bracing for a “mini-revolution” as the county’s president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, is forced to adapt to life without his closest adviser, chief enforcer and most loyal associate, Andriy Yermak, who resigned on Friday after his apartment was searched as part of a widening anti-corruption probe.Yermak’s resignation could have tremendous consequences for domestic governance, as well as for Ukraine’s negotiating position in talks over ending the war with Russia, where he had served as the head of Ukraine’s delegation to peace talks with the White House. Continue reading...

items.title: Ukraine peace talks shaken up by resignation of Zelenskyy's top aide in corruption probe
items.standfirst: Just as peace talks were gaining traction, Ukraine has lost its lead negotiator
items.content: Just as peace talks were gaining traction, Ukraine has lost its lead negotiator

items.title: Fall of Zelensky's top aide - reboot for Kyiv or costly shake-up?
items.standfirst: A widening corruption scandal forced Ukraine's second most powerful person, Andriy Yermak, to resign.
items.content: A widening corruption scandal forced Ukraine's second most powerful person, Andriy Yermak, to resign.

items.title: Zelensky removes top aide and negotiator after anti-graft raids
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky removed his powerful chief of staff and top negotiator on Friday, after detectives raided Andriy Yermak's house as part of a sweeping corruption probe. Yermak's removal deals a serious blow to Zelensky, who faces a mounting Russian offensive in the east as Washington peddles a plan to end the war that Kyiv fears will hand big concessions to Moscow.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky removed his powerful chief of staff and top negotiator on Friday, after detectives raided Andriy Yermak's house as part of a sweeping corruption probe. Yermak's removal deals a serious blow to Zelensky, who faces a mounting Russian offensive in the east as Washington peddles a plan to end the war that Kyiv fears will hand big concessions to Moscow.

items.title: Top Zelenskyy aide at heart of U.S. peace talks resigns after being implicated in corruption probe
items.standfirst: A top Ukrainian official at the heart of peace talks resigned on Friday after being thrust into the center of a massive corruption scandal, threatening to further weaken President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at a crucial moment in negotiations to end Russia’s war
items.content: A top Ukrainian official at the heart of peace talks resigned on Friday after being thrust into the center of a massive corruption scandal, threatening to further weaken President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at a crucial moment in negotiations to end Russia’s war

ai_summary: Andriy Yermak resigned as Zelenskyy's top aide.
Yermak's apartment was searched as part of a probe.
His resignation could impact peace talks.
Zelenskyy faces a mounting Russian offensive.
The resignation is a serious blow to Zelenskyy.

clusters.title: Experts say top FDA official’s claim that Covid vaccines caused kids’ deaths requires more evidence
clusters.neutral_headline: FDA Official Claims COVID Vaccines Caused Child Deaths

items.title: Experts say top FDA official’s claim that Covid vaccines caused kids’ deaths requires more evidence

items.title: Trump casts long shadow over Honduran politics ahead of vote
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Friday made a major intervention into Honduran politics days before the Central American nation votes, pardoning a convicted ex-leader and threatening to cut US support if his preferred candidate loses. Trump said he will pardon ex-president Juan Orlando Hernandez, who was convicted last year in a US court of drug trafficking charges and sentenced to 45 years in prison.

items.standfirst: The university will pay $75 million over three years to end the Trump administration's investigations into antisemitism on its campus and to have millions of dollars in federal funding restored.
items.content: The university will pay $75 million over three years to end the Trump administration's investigations into antisemitism on its campus and to have millions of dollars in federal funding restored.(Image credit: Teresa Crawford)

items.title: Northwestern University agrees to pay US government $75m to restore research funding
items.standfirst: Agreement will also end series of investigations of university over school’s alleged failure to fight antisemitismNorthwestern University has agreed to pay $75m to the US government in a deal with the Trump administration to end a series of investigations and restore hundreds of millions of dollars in federal research funding.Donald Trump’s administration had cut off $790m in grants in a standoff that contributed to university layoffs and the resignation in September of Northwestern’s president, Michael Schill. The administration argued the school had not done enough to fight antisemitism. Continue reading...
items.content: Agreement will also end series of investigations of university over school’s alleged failure to fight antisemitismNorthwestern University has agreed to pay $75m to the US government in a deal with the Trump administration to end a series of investigations and restore hundreds of millions of dollars in federal research funding.Donald Trump’s administration had cut off $790m in grants in a standoff that contributed to university layoffs and the resignation in September of Northwestern’s president, Michael Schill. The administration argued the school had not done enough to fight antisemitism. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Kyiv tries to pile pressure on Russia with attack on empty vessels on way to load up with oil for foreign marketsUkrainian naval drones hit two tankers operating under sanctions in the Black Sea as they headed to a Russian port to load up with oil destined for foreign markets, an official said on Saturday, as Kyiv tries to pile pressure on Russia’s vast oil industry.The two oil tankers, identified as the Kairos and Virat, were empty and sailing to Novorossiysk, a major Russian Black Sea oil terminal, the official at the security service of Ukraine told Reuters. items.title: Tattoo Ink Moves Through the Body, Killing Immune Cells and Weakening Vaccine Response
items.standfirst: Tattoo ink doesn’t just sit inertly in the skin. New research shows it moves rapidly into the lymphatic system, where it can persist for months, kill immune cells, and even disrupt how the body responds to vaccines.
items.content: Tattoo ink doesn’t just sit inertly in the skin. New research shows it moves rapidly into the lymphatic system, where it can persist for months, kill immune cells, and even disrupt how the body responds to vaccines.

ai_summary: Tattoo ink accumulates in lymph nodes, according to a study.
Ink drains into the lymphatic system after tattooing.
Ink accumulation diminishes the effects of immune cells.
The ink triggers local and systemic inflammation.
The inflammation persists for months after tattooing.

items.title: Amid ‘instability and fear’ in Trump’s economy, Americans are cutting holiday spending
items.standfirst: In addition to rising prices and tariffs, readers cite growing unemployment as a reason not to exchange gifts this yearAmericans are feeling rattled about the state of the economy. Donald Trump has batted away question after question from reporters on concerns over higher prices, just a year after he won an election promising to bring down costs.While the White House has tried to reduce concern, floating tariff-funded $2,000 stimulus checks and removing import levies on certain agricultural imports, many consumers remain anxious. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Americans are cutting holiday spending due to economic concerns.
Rising prices and tariffs are contributing to the economic anxiety.
Growing unemployment is another factor influencing spending habits.
The White House has attempted to reduce concerns.
Many consumers remain anxious about the economy.

clusters.title: Hong Kong mourns victims of deadly building fire
clusters.neutral_headline: Hong Kong mourns victims of deadly building fire

items.title: Hong Kong mourns victims of deadly building fire
items.standfirst: An outpouring of grief swept Hong Kong on Saturday as thousands paid their respects and laid flowers for the 128 people killed in one of the city's deadliest fires, marking the start of an official, three-day mourning period. People from across the city flocked to a small park near the charred shell of Wang Fuk Court, the residential complex that burned for more than 40 hours, to place white and yellow flowers and leave handwritten messages of remembrance.
items.content: An outpouring of grief swept Hong Kong on Saturday as thousands paid their respects and laid flowers for the 128 people killed in one of the city's deadliest fires, marking the start of an official, three-day mourning period. People from across the city flocked to a small park near the charred shell of Wang Fuk Court, the residential complex that burned for more than 40 hours, to place white and yellow flowers and leave handwritten messages of remembrance.

items.title: Hong Kong begins three days of mourning after deadly apartment fires
items.standfirst: Families are combing hospitals hoping to find their loved ones as about 200 people still listed as missing, and at least 128 killedAn outpouring of grief was set to sweep Hong Kong on Saturday as an official, three-day mourning period began with a moment of silence for the 128 people killed in one of the city’s deadliest fires.City leader John Lee, along with senior ministers and dozens of top civil servants, stood in silence for three minutes on Saturday morning outside the government headquarters, where the flags of China and Hong Kong were flown at half-mast. Continue reading...
items.content: Families are combing hospitals hoping to find their loved ones as about 200 people still listed as missing, and at least 128 killedAn outpouring of grief was set to sweep Hong Kong on Saturday as an official, three-day mourning period began with a moment of silence for the 128 people killed in one of the city’s deadliest fires.City leader John Lee, along with senior ministers and dozens of top civil servants, stood in silence for three minutes on Saturday morning outside the government headquarters, where the flags of China and Hong Kong were flown at half-mast. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hong Kong is in mourning after a deadly building fire.
The fire resulted in 128 fatalities.
Thousands paid respects and laid flowers.
An official three-day mourning period began.
Families are searching for missing loved ones.

clusters.title: Video shows Israeli forces shooting Palestinians dead moments after surrender
clusters.neutral_headline: Video Shows Israeli Forces Killing Palestinians After Surrender

items.title: Video shows Israeli forces shooting Palestinians dead moments after surrender
items.standfirst: Far-right minister defends killing of two men who appeared to have given themselves up, saying ‘terrorists must die’Video of an Israeli military raid in the West Bank shows soldiers summarily executing two Palestinians they had detained seconds earlier.The shooting on Thursday evening, which was also witnessed by journalists close to the scene, is under justice ministry review, but has already been defended by Israel’s far-right minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, who declared that “terrorists must die”. Continue reading...
items.content: Far-right minister defends killing of two men who appeared to have given themselves up, saying ‘terrorists must die’Video of an Israeli military raid in the West Bank shows soldiers summarily executing two Palestinians they had detained seconds earlier.The shooting on Thursday evening, which was also witnessed by journalists close to the scene, is under justice ministry review, but has already been defended by Israel’s far-right minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, who declared that “terrorists must die”. Continue reading...

items.title: Israeli forces kill two Palestinians after they appear to surrender
items.standfirst: Israeli security forces shot and killed two Palestinian men who appeared to be unarmed and surrendering in the occupied West Bank on Thursday, according to video filmed by Palestine TV that was distributed by Reuters, and video shot by the news agency itself
items.content: Israeli security forces shot and killed two Palestinian men who appeared to be unarmed and surrendering in the occupied West Bank on Thursday, according to video filmed by Palestine TV that was distributed by Reuters, and video shot by the news agency itself

ai_summary: Video footage shows Israeli soldiers shooting two Palestinians in the West Bank.
The Palestinians appeared to have surrendered moments before the shooting occurred.
The Israeli justice ministry is reviewing the incident captured on video.
A far-right Israeli minister defended the killings, stating "terrorists must die".
The shooting was witnessed by journalists present at the scene.
